title: 103_hr2808
content: The Act may be cited as the "Depository Institutions Disaster Relief Act of 1993". It includes provisions related to the Truth in Lending Act and the Expedited Funds Availability Act. During the 180-day period after the Act's enactment, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System can grant exceptions to the Truth in Lending Act and the Expedited Funds Availability Act for areas affected by disasters, if deemed necessary to alleviate public hardships. The Federal Reserve can grant exceptions to the Expedited Funds Availability Act for depository institutions in disaster-affected areas to alleviate public hardships. Any exception made shall expire within 1 year of enactment or determination. The Board must publish a statement describing and explaining any exceptions made. The Federal Reserve can grant exceptions to the Expedited Funds Availability Act for depository institutions in disaster-affected areas to alleviate public hardships, with any exception expiring within 1 year. The Board must publish a statement explaining how the exception can benefit the public more than any adverse effects. SEC. 3. DEPOSIT OF INSURANCE PROCEEDS. During an 18-month period after the enactment of this Act, a Federal banking agency can allow an insured depository institution to deduct a qualifying amount of insurance proceeds from its total assets when calculating compliance with the leverage limit. This is permitted if the institution's principal place of business is in an area declared a major disaster area by the President or eligible for disaster relief under Federal law. The Federal banking agency can permit an insured depository institution to deduct insurance proceeds from its total assets for leverage limit compliance if it meets certain criteria, including being in a major disaster area and having an acceptable plan for managing increased assets and deposits. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act defines key terms such as "appropriate federal banking agency," "insured depository institution," "leverage limit," and "qualifying amount attributable to insurance proceeds." The Federal Deposit Insurance Act defines terms related to insurance payments or governmental assistance for damage caused by a major disaster. SEC. 4. BANKING AGENCY PUBLICATION REQUIREMENTS. During the 180-day period after the enactment of this Act, a qualifying regulatory agency can take actions to assist depository institutions or regulated entities in areas affected by a major disaster, without full compliance with certain provisions of law. A qualifying regulatory agency can take actions to assist institutions affected by a major disaster without full compliance with certain provisions of law, including publication requirements for establishing branches or deposit-taking facilities. The agency must publish a statement in the Federal Register describing any action taken under this section. A qualifying regulatory agency, as defined in this section, includes various federal agencies such as the Federal Reserve, Comptroller of the Currency, and others. These agencies can take actions to assist institutions affected by a major disaster without full compliance with certain provisions of law. The agency must publish a statement in the Federal Register explaining the need for the action taken. SEC. 5. STUDY; REPORT TO THE CONGRESS. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the authority granted by the Depository Institutions Disaster Relief Act of 1992 and this Act, evaluating their effectiveness in disaster recovery for depository institutions. Recommendations on making the authority permanent will be included in a report to Congress within 18 months. The Congress urges financial institutions to support communities affected by the 1993 Mississippi River flooding. No limitations on other agency authorities.
